title: 105_hr3573
content: Limitation on disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to certain countries. Section 5302 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to limit disbursements from the Exchange Stabilization Fund to foreign countries not in compliance with IMF commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot exceed $500,000,000 for international rescue plans unless the country meets IMF reform commitments. The Secretary of the Treasury must certify to Congress that a foreign country is meeting its IMF commitments before disbursing funds from the Exchange Stabilization Fund. The Secretary also considers all expenditures made for the country in the previous 6 months to determine if the limit has been exceeded. The Secretary of the Treasury considers all expenditures made for a foreign country in the previous 6 months before disbursing funds from the Exchange Stabilization Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury reports to Congress on US actions to monitor foreign government compliance with commitments to the IMF in financial assistance packages. The Secretary of the Treasury reports to Congress semiannually on US efforts to monitor Asian foreign governments' compliance with IMF commitments in financial assistance packages. The report includes actions taken by the US Executive Director at the IMF and the Department of the Treasury to ensure effective monitoring and enforcement. The Executive Director at the International Monetary Fund ensures effective monitoring and enforcement of commitments, while the Department of the Treasury coordinates actions with the Office of the United States Trade Representative or the Department of Commerce. SEC. 3. Monitoring the effects of the Asian financial crisis on the United States and other economies. The Commerce Department, in coordination with the United States Trade Representative, will monitor Asian countries receiving financial assistance to ensure they comply with international agreements on market access. Reports will be submitted to Congress every two months until assistance is terminated, including progress on resolving trade disputes. The reports to Congress will detail progress on resolving trade disputes, implementing trade obligations, and market access issues in Asian countries receiving financial assistance. The reports to Congress will detail progress on resolving trade disputes, implementing trade obligations, and market access issues in Asian countries receiving financial assistance. The report will include information on Korea's implementation of trade obligations, Indonesia's compliance with commitments to end the "National Car" program, and the extent of reforms in corporate governance and structure in various countries. The report to Congress will include details on implementing reform measures required by the International Monetary Fund to improve corporate governance and structure, such as transparency in accounting practices and preventing government subsidies to prevent financial failure in specific industries. It will also cover deregulation, privatization, and trade liberalization efforts in various countries. The report to Congress will detail the implementation of reform measures required by the International Monetary Fund to deregulate and privatize economic activity in industries like semiconductor, steel, motor vehicles, and paper. It will also discuss trade policies, including unfair practices and adverse effects on the United States, as well as instances where Asian countries have failed to provide market access for foreign goods and services. The Secretary and the United States Trade Representative will take action against Asian countries failing to provide market access for foreign goods and services. The Commerce Department will monitor exports from Asian countries receiving financial assistance to assess market openness by Japan, the European Union, and other major IMF participants. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor Asian exports to assess market access by Japan, the EU, and other IMF participants. Reports will be submitted to Congress every two months until financial assistance ends. Actions will be taken to ensure fair burden-sharing in response to the Asian financial crisis. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor Asian exports to the US for any significant increase due to currency fluctuations, subsidies, dumping, or transshipment. This is to ensure fair burden-sharing in response to the Asian financial crisis. The Secretary of Commerce will monitor Asian exports to the US for any significant increase due to currency fluctuations, subsidies, dumping, or transshipment. This monitoring will take into account antidumping and countervailing duty determinations on imports from Asian countries. The Secretary will report to Congress bimonthly until financial assistance for each country is terminated and will take appropriate action under US laws if evidence of dumping or subsidization causing injury to US industries is found. Consultation with import-sensitive US industries will be conducted for sharing purposes. The Secretary of Commerce will consult with import-sensitive US industries to share relevant information and views. The Secretary, in consultation with the US Trade Representative, will report annually to Congress on the impact of financial assistance on trade relations between Asian countries and others. SEC. 4. FULL ENFORCEMENT OF TRADE LAW REMEDIES. The Secretary of Commerce will conduct a study with import-sensitive US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws to imports from Asian countries affected by currency devaluations and financial assistance. The study will address rapid fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws. The Secretary of Commerce will study the impact of currency devaluations and financial assistance on US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws. This includes addressing fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws and determining appropriate treatment for subsidies and interest rate differences under countervailing duty laws. The Secretary of Commerce will study the impact of currency devaluations and financial assistance on US industries to determine the application of antidumping and countervailing duty laws. This includes addressing fluctuations in exchange rates to prevent undermining US antidumping laws and determining appropriate treatment for subsidies received in the past under countervailing duty laws. The study will be completed within 6 months, and a report will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 5. SUNSET. The provisions of this Act will end 8 years after its enactment.
